bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to W.F. de Niedman, April 10, 1928

div1.p: Kean informs de Niedman that he will testify on behalf of a pension bill to recognize the work of the yellow fever commission and volunteers, including Agramonte.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to W.F. de Niedman, April 10, 1928
div1.opener:
10 April, 1928.
Dr. W. F. de Niedman,
Los Altos, California.
My dear Major de Niedman:
div1.p:
Your letter of the 4th came yesterday and I read it
with much interest. It takes us a long way back, more than a
quarter of a century, to those days in Cuba when we were so much
occupied with the mystery and dread of yellow fever. I am going
up tomorrow with the Surgeon General to a hearing before the
Military Committee of the House about a proposition which has been
started by Professor James E. Peabody of New York and some other
men of good will to give proper recognition on the part of the
Government to the work of the Reed Board and adequate pensions to
the families of Reed and his assistants, and to the men who under-
went the yellow fever experiments. Incidentally we want adequate
recognition for Agramonte whose work as a member of the Reed Board
has never been properly recognized, and who has never received any-
thing in the way of honor or reward from our Government. I think
your suggestion is a fine one that advantage be taken of the re-
union of the Spanish War Veterans in Havana this fall to do honor
to Agramonte. I hope you will take it up with whoever are the
leaders in the meeting. I am not a member of the Spanish War
Veterans; I do not know exactly why except that I am not much of a
joiner.
With thanks for your letter and best wishes, I am
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J.R. KEAN,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.
